article.headline: Michigan 70, Delaware St. 43
article.story: ANN ARBOR, Mich. (AP) -- The fear of a long week of practices was the motivation Michigan needed against Delaware State. After being challenged at halftime by coach Tommy Amaker, the Wolverines responded with an impressive defensive performance and went on to rout the Hornets 70-43 on Saturday. Amaker's ultimatum to his players was to hold Delaware State to below 50 points. Michigan was leading 37-26 at the time. "We want to really do that for him because we know if we don't do that, we're going to have a tough time in practice," said Dion Harris, who led the Wolverines with 16 points. "That's what motivates us." Brent Petway, who along with Courtney Sims had 12 points, said fear was also involved. "We had to really come out in the second half," Petway said. "He's done that a couple of times this year where he's given us a point margin where we've got to hold a team to. Definitely, there's a fear there. "One time this year we missed that margin and we had a week before we played, and it was a long week." After building a 37-26 halftime lead, Michigan (10-1) blew the game open by outscoring Delaware State 14-4 to open the second half. The Wolverines took advantage of continued cold shooting by the Hornets and led by as many as 29 points. The Hornets (2-8) made only six of 26 shots from the field in the half. Delaware State coach Greg Jackson blamed the Hornets' second-half difficulties on Michigan's defensive intensity. "They came out and made us put the ball on the floor to create a shot, and that's not our strength," Jackson said. "Any time that we have to put the ball on the floor to create our own shot, we're not going to beat very many teams. They realized that it was our weakness and they exploited it." The Wolverines' victory was marred by a technical foul called with 17:41 left on Sims, who was struggling for a rebound with the Hornets' Troy Roundtree. Sims appeared to swing an elbow at Roundtree, who had also grabbed the ball. Delaware State stayed closed through the first six minutes by hitting six of its first eight shots to tie the game at 14. Michigan followed with an 18-4 run to take its largest lead of the first half. The Wolverines had one of their better opening halves of the season, hitting 60 percent of their shots from the field, including five of eight 3-pointers. Roy Bright had 21 points for the Hornets, who are playing their first 14 games of the season on the road. Michigan is 9-0 at home this season and has won 12 straight nonconference games at Crisler Arena. "It was nice to see how we started the second half," Amaker said. "We had great energy and we were able to finish a solid performance this afternoon against a team that has played well against some high-caliber opponents."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
